data.name: Parsing webmentions
data.content:
Thanks to everyone who helped me test webmentions that I hacked together at Indie Web Camp last weekend.

Let me explain what web mentions are all about‚Ä¶

Basically, it‚Äôs an equivalent to pingback. Let‚Äôs say I write something here on adactio.com. Suppose that prompts you to write something in response on your own site. A web mention is a way for you to let me know that your response exists.

If you look in the head of any of my journal posts, you‚Äôll see this link element:

<link rel="webmention" href="http://adactio.com/webmention.php" />

That‚Äôs my web mention endpoint: http://adactio.com/webmention.php ‚Ä¶it‚Äôs kind of like a webhook: a URL that‚Äôs intended to be hit by machines rather than people. So when you publish your response to my post, you ping that URL with a POST request that sends two parameters:

  1. target: the URL of my post and
  2. source: the URL of your response.

Ideally your own CMS or blogging system would take care of doing the pinging, but until that‚Äôs more widely implemented, I‚Äôm providing this form at the end of each of my posts:

Either way, once you ping my web mention endpoint‚Äîdiscoverable through that link rel="webmention"‚Äîwith those two parameters, I just need to confirm that your post does indeed contain a link to my post‚Äîby making a cURL request and parsing your source‚Äîand then I return a server response of 202 (Accepted).

Here‚Äôs the code for a minimum viable web mention in PHP.

That‚Äôs as far as I got at Indie Web Camp but it was enough for me to start collecting responses to posts.

The next step is to do something with the responses. After all, I‚Äôve already got the source of each response from those cURL requests.

Barnaby has a written a nice straightforward microformats parser in PHP. I‚Äôm using that to check the cURLed source for any responses that have been marked up using h-entry. That‚Äôs one of the microformats 2 vocabularies‚Äîa much simpler way of writing structured content with microformats.

Aaron, Amber, and Barnaby all sent responses that were marked up with h-entry so now their responses appear in full.

So there you have it. Comments are now open on every journal post on adactio.com ‚Ä¶the only catch is that you have to write the comment on your own site. And if you want the content of your post to appear here (instead of just a link) then update your blog post template to include a handful of h-entry classes.

Feel free to use this post as a test. Mark up your blog with h-entry, write a post that links to this URL, and enter the URL of your post in the form below.
retweeted this.

data.name: New service: WebMentions for static pages
data.content:
I'm now launching a service that can receive and embeds WebMentions for sites. Useful for eg. static blogs on GitHub Pages.

Earlier this year when I went to the IndieWebCamp in Brighton, a very nice event, the thing people were most excited about, at least when it came to the actually implementing it, was WebMentions.

So when it was time to get hands on with code I wanted to do so as well, my only trouble was: This blog is on Jekyll/GitHub Pages since two years and I like it there. How can I then accept something as dynamic as a comment from someone elses blog?

I know you‚Äôre already thinking it ‚Äì a hosted solution like Disqus could surely solve my problem and yes indeed, therefore I went ahead and built one. Then came ordinary life and occupied me with other stuff, but now finally a very first rough version is ready for launch and can be found at webmention.herokuapp.com.

This post will prove that it works by appearing as the first WebMention on webmention.herokuapp.com itself and hopefully mentions from others will start appearing both there and on this blog eventually so that maybe I‚Äôll become as cool as Aaron Parecki, Jeremy Keith and the others in the end.

I‚Äôm aware that this service isn‚Äôt totally inline with the spirit of the IndieWeb, that you should own and host your own stuff (I‚Äôm not even using IndieAuth yet!), but it‚Äôs my pragmatic solution for getting a step closer to such a world and a solution I‚Äôm happy to share with others.

I‚Äôm opening up just five accounts for others now, considering this is still an early alpha, and will keep the development open on GitHub ‚Äì all feedback is welcome!

Bridgy ist ein WebMention Proxy f√ºr Twitter, Facebook und Google+. Es sammelt comments, shares, likes und re-tweets und leitet sie an die entsprechenden Links weiter.

Bridgy sends webmentions for comments, likes, and reshares on Facebook, Twitter, Google+, and Instagram. Bridgy notices when you post links, watches for activity on those posts, and sends them back to your site as webmentions. It also serves them as microformats2 for webmention targets to read.

Gro√üartige Idee!

Wer sein eigenes Bridgy betreiben will‚Ä¶ der Code ist Open Source!

So I guess *maybe* this counts for 512kB club? Definitely in blue team range though...

@ralismark At least this gives me plenty of stuff to write about -- there aren't many blog posts about doing what I did with Jekyll plugins
@ralismark you could try short pixel to reduce the size of the images. Or replace your remote fonts with a local font stack.
@ralismark Sorry system not local font stack!
@ralismark Images size can be reduced by using WebP format.

@ralismark For the Merriweather/Google Font API, I'd suggest just switching to a local font stack:
https://www.wpmediamastery.com/why-and-how-to-use-a-system-font-stack/

Chrome and FIrefox recently changed how font cache works in their browsers for privacy reasons, so more reason to not use Google Fonts:

https://www.zdnet.com/article/chromes-new-cache-partitioning-system-impacts-google-fonts-performance/

and

https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2020/12/firefox-v85-will-improve-its-cache-partitioning-for-stronger-privacy/

Why And How To Use A System Font Stack (Huge Benefits) 2021

@ralismark That's very english centric, langauges like german is better in regards to following a sane orthography, Now my own language is at times wild since I read a completely different word than what's written since I speak a different tialect, I still often read "hund" as "bikkje" for example if I don't take extra care to read the text as written.
@ralismark roll tap and retroflex are the ones used my mothertongue, now yo're not that weird, a couple of weeks ago I read a 150 page master's thesis about retroflex sounds :p

@ralismark QMK has this neat feature called mod-tap, where a key can be a modifier if held or a standard keypress if pressed. I use it to bind capslock to control if held and escape if pressed. It works surprisingly well.

Also that's a very nice looking keyboard you have there.

@ralismark Thanks for sharing!
